subject: Re: [junit] Re: Anyone know of a decent debugger?
msgSnippet: ... There is usually an underlying mental assertion when using System.out, for example.  You see the result and compare it mentally to an expected outcome.
messageBody:
mamago@... wrote:

>
> I find that I understand the code much better using System.out
> statements rather than trying to find my way round existing Java
> debuggers, which IME have found lacking. (Maybe the suggestions in
> this thread will help me change that.)
>

There is usually an underlying mental assertion when using System.out, for
example. You see the result and compare it mentally to an expected outcome.
This is important information for you and the next person to touch the code,
so I suggest it's best codified by a test that lives beyond the debugging
session.

>
> > Moreover, logging debug messages at this granularity tends to
> > reduce the
> > readability of the code, in my experience.
>
> I agree. If you use debug output/log statements, they are there to
> perform a specific task: find a bug. Once located and exterminated,
> their function is over, take them out.
>

The OP suggested using debug logging and then turning them off, rather than
taking them out. I agree that if used for debugging, they should be
removed.... and replaced by a test.

Finding the bug is usually the most time-consuming step; fixing it usually
takes less time. I have noticed that I usually can't stuff enough context
information into debug messages as I'd like, and this slows down my
debugging. Rather, if I can capture that context in a test, it's easier to
find.

So, when I find myself wanting to use debug logging statements, I'll attempt
to write a test instead to verify my assertions. This isn't always easy, but
many times it leads to some well-deserved refactoring that I think make it
worth it. If I don't already have a good test suite, then it may take some
time to isolate the bug, but in the end this yields a more comprehensive set
of tests. I'm still learning...

Mike
